newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine bonds rise, maintaining strong tone.
newsitem.headline: Argentine bonds rise, maintaining strong tone.

text.p: Argentine bonds were higher Wednesday as the stronger sentiment of late maintained its grip on the market.
"The market's mood is good," said a trader at a large foreign bank.
Traders said there was nothing specific expected this session but that the feeling was a greater push by government to get its economic policies passed in Congress is underway.

The meeting called by President Carlos Menem Thursday of the ruling Peronist Party is seen as a clear indication that the government is going to put more effort into persuading reluctant Congressmen to support the government line.
The 5.5 percent dollar-denominated Bocon Previsional 2 due 2001 rose $0.20 to 116.30 while Argentina's FRB advanced 1/2 to 79-3/8.
An analyst at a large foreign bank said another issue in marks Wednesday after two bonds on Tuesday is also helping even though the issue only amounted to 75 million marks.
A crucial question for Argentine market watchers is whether the current rising budget deficit can be financed, so any new issuance is positive since it alleviates the pressure on fiscal policy.
Argentina sold a seven year FRB linked bond with a 11 percent coupon at a price of 99.75.
